They destroyed more than 1,000 synagogues and 7,000 Jewish businesses, looted and burned homes, and arrested and deported more than 30,000 Jewish men to concentration camps.

2. Deportations: Between 1938 and 1942, more than 65,000 Austrian Jews were deported to ghettos and concentration camps in Germany and other countries. Many were stripped of their possessions, their homes, and their citizenship.

3. Forced Labor: Austrian Jews were forced to work in factories, construction sites, and farms under harsh conditions. Many were subjected to physical abuse and forced to work long hours with little food and rest.

4. School and work discrimination: After the Anschluss, Austrian Jews were excluded from schools and universities. They were also forced out of their jobs, businesses, and professions, and were often replaced by non-Jewish Austrians.

Buchenwald Trials: In 1947, a series of trials were held in Austria against former SS members who were accused of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in the Buchenwald concentration camp. These are just some of the examples of the violence and persecution that Austrian Jews faced after the Anschluss.

4. Forced labor: Jews were forced into hard labor, often working in factories and construction sites, with little or no pay. Many died from exhaustion, disease, and malnutrition.

5. Deportation to concentration and death camps: After being rounded up and stripped of their belongings, Jews were loaded onto cattle cars for transport to concentration camps, where they faced terrible conditions, including forced labor, starvation, and medical experimentation.

6. Mass murder: Many were ultimately sent to death camps, such as Auschwitz-Birkenau and Treblinka, where they were immediately gassed upon arrival.

Overall, the deportation of Jews from Austria was a horrific experience, marked by immense cruelty and brutality.
